This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK andamp; SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN andamp; Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. andamp; O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK andamp; SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The trouble in Natal
div.p: In the House of Commons yesterday MR. Winston Churchill accpeted the motion urging that the Imperial Government should be responsible for the protection of natives in South Africa. He said that the GOvernmnet determind to insist on the proper tratment of natives by Colonual Governments. Referring to the events in Natal, Mr. Winston CHurchilll said that while there was no reason for immediate apprehension. the situation required carful and patien attention. Although we have not as yet sufficient dat on whcih to form an estimate of the gravity of the recent disturbamc in ANtal we have one piece of infromation the significane of whcih it is worth while to consdier. The men who refused tp apy the poll tax belong to what is calleda genric term-- the Ethiopian Church. Now, such an outbreak on the part of Christian natve is a new startling feature in South Africa. Ethopoianism (says Mr. Archibald R. Coloquhoun in an interesting article in the "Morning Post"), which dates pratically from 1896, through the first move was made in 1892, has been the subject of careful study since its inception/ in utward seeming it is merely a Church secessionist movement having its orgin, not doctrinal diffences, but in the question of Chruch discipline. The Protestant Chrihces, more especially the Nonconfor,ist, which are in the habit conferring orders with some freedom on their best converts, have been most affected by the movement, which has spread throughout the South African Colonies and even to Rhodiesia. the ROman Cathokic and Moravian Missions, whcia dmit no natives to odres, have not been touched, and the Augclican chirch has felt secessionist influences least of all the pROTESTAT BODIES. tHIS CIRCUMSTNACE, whcih Mr. Colquhoun veriifed in some detial, leaves no doubt as to the origin of the movement. It has proved impossible to start the native on a certain path and yet put an arbitray stop to his progress. The democratic consitutions of the Noncomformist Churches have laid them specially opent to this course of

development, and although the missionaries' ideal most have included the altimate'independence of their e.nverts, yet its premature realisation has filled them with sorprise and alarm. The Surpise a lay point of view, has been the power of orgnaization shown by the African native for the first time outside his tribe.

A very important pnut is the social organisation of the secessionist churches, which, under native oootrol, becomea sjibrtitate for the tribal life. The British Government is anxious to preserve the tribal organisation, bat varioao influences are at work undermining it. Christianity frequently destroys it and detaches the individual from his own people. In. Natal the wise policy has been adopted of sub-dividing the tribes, so that at present there are three hundred and twelve, each having its onw chief, who is paid by the GOVERNMENT. bUT the tribal ohief may find himself in direct opposition to the eoolesiastioal authority which some of his people recognise, as appears to have been the oase in the teoent inoident. We • 1 ^ k . 4 % ♦ ' do not mean that the Church to which the rebels belonged aotoally was an instigating force, bat that their membership of it supplied them with the neoessary support A native is so aooustomed to tribal • action that he will . . • • • never aot individually. This tendency bf the Ethiopian Churoh to form a new social organi- sation which . will supplant the tribe is one that must be earefnlly watched.

Naturallt the character of this new factor in native life is of the greates importance. missionaires lays tress on the low moral standard and absence of dsicipline found in it, and there is good evidence that their charges are well founded. As regards the poltical significance of tehis movmeent, mr. Coloquhoun finds himself at variance with the NATIVE aFFIARS COMMISSION, WHICH SEEMS TO CONSDIERa that at present ethcipianism is a a religious and not a political or ant-white, movemtn. His own view is that it is not so much intentioanlly as essentially political, having its basins in race cleavage. The natal native trist has set its face sternly against ethiopianism, forbidding any church to be started or maintained without European supervison. THIS Does not, however affect the whole colony, and there are as many as nine speartist chirchs in antal. The refusal to allow without special licences had been granted up to the time of the last report (1905). The Native Affairs Commission recommended this as a useful repressive measure, and it is indeed hard to think of any which would not be regardued as harsh, while at the same time some control is absolutely necessary. The difficulty is to steer the way between persecution and indifferenc.

Natal has such a very small white population that any symptom of unrest among its native people must cause uneasiness, but the dificulties are not be met by evading them. The uestion of taxation is a delicate one and certainly needs adjustment, and the poll tax was, of course, intended to reach a class whcih, while earning good wages, does not contribute in the form of hut tax. Whether it was wise at the present time to impose a form of taxation alien to native custom is open to dpubt, but thepolciy of the Natal governemnt regarding its native peoples i, like that, of every other soutehr african governemnt, too prone to disregard the very serious changes taking palce in native life and character. The crux ot the situation lies deeper than mere local circumstances. The whole systmem in SOuth Africa needs adjusting with a view to defining the true position of the native and giving him legitmate outlets for an enegy which si being artificially repressed. Above all, the encesisity for uniformity in native policy is a crying need, for while the whole social and legal status of a native depends on the latitutde in whcih eh finds hismelf, it will be imposible to govern with logic and justice.

div.head: Bank of Abyssinia
div.p: We are informed from a reliable source " says onr Paris contemporary, "L'E flair," in its latest issue, "that eight or ten days ago one of the important personalities of the Pavil'on de Flore, whose connection is well known with the most influential authorities of the Com- psgnie da Chemin de Fer Etbiop:eu and who has always shown himself an indisoreetly enthusiastic partiaau of the internationalisation of the line, has laid a most singular soheme before the committee for foreign and cilon'al affairs. The Bank of Abyssinia (the Ciwsel Bank) would, aooording to this arrangement, take the affair op again and engage to pay the nonpars, which have been held in abeyance, to the bondholders. In exchange it would he privileged to reoeive the 10 per oent. duty on all goodB oonveyed aloDg the lice. The existence of this duty, however, has never been" very clearly established, and its collection is in praotioe impossible. It is well to remember that Cai-sel'a are the private bankers of King Edward VII. In fact, the arrangement as above announced would be a pure and simple surrender of the whole enterprise to England. It mnst at onoe be added that the committee happily refused to discuss the scheme, and that it was rejected also by the Mini-t-y of Foreign • Aff *ir», bat it is affirmed that the offi ial of the Colonial Ministry who was. if not the deviser, at least the endorser of th- soheme does not oonsider trmre f defeated and proposes to return onoe m ire to the charge."

div.head: A ROYAL TRAVELLER.
div.p: The Duke of the Abruzzi is arriving at Poit Said next month on his way toUganda, whence \ Bourse, he will return by way of the Nile and Khar toum to Cairo. The Duke of the Abrocci intends ascending the Rnwenzori mountain, which is 6,£00 metres in height. This peak, which is known by the natives as the King of the Ciond , has sneoet-sfally resisted the attempts of snob we l-ki own olnubers and explorers as Baker, Gessi, Mason Bey in 1877, Stanley—who was the nearest to^the top—Emin Paoha in 1888, and Soott-Elliott in 1893, to oonqaer it. The Rnwenrori is hidden by mist aod c'ouds f* r 30 ) days in the year, and the forests leading to it are inhabited by warike tribes, hostile to European*. The Royal Alpinists will be accompanied by nine Italians, including Capt Umberto Cagni, Dr. Cavalli, Lieutenant E iooardo Winspeare.the famous gaides Vittorio Sella, Botta, Fenvillet, and his son, all of whom, ex iept the last mentioned, were members of the DukeV Polar expedition, and shared the pleasures and dangers ot several other tri, s.

div.head: FRONTIER DISPUTE. NEGOTIATIONS UNOPENED. ANOTHER ATTEMPTED OCCUPATION
div.p: The qnestion of the Akaba boundary has Dot yet been submitted to negotiation in Cairo. The Ottoman delegates are reported to be awaiting .the arrival of inspections from 0 >nsf aople ntin

Kaimakam Barker Bey and Naonm Bey Shukeir, officials of the Sudan Governin'nt, returned on Wednesday frem Akaba, where they were present at the negotiations between the Ottoman and Egyp ian officials in regard to tie Akaba difficulty.
The Ottoman and Egyptian delegates will probably leave together for Akaba in a tew days and Ewen Bey and Naoum 3ey Shnkeir will accompany I-miil Pacha Serhauk to the frontier in dispute.

The situation in regard to he fron ier dispnta last week appears to have been much strained, and the new-of the Turks' intention to oooopy the island of Faraon was not aHowad to filter through to the looal Press in Egypt. According to a Renter's telegram published in the London papers the Egyptian G ivernment informed the British Foreign Minister that tho ounmander of the Turks at Akaba was preparing to occupy the small island of Faraon which was andoqbted y within the limits of Egyptian administration. Sir Elward Grey commnnioated this news to Masurns Pandoha, the Ottoman Ambassador in London and the Porta therefore deoided to de-pandtoh a oom mission of erquiry.
The Constantinople correspondent of the "Daily Te'egraph," telegraphing last week says:—

' It is teared that 'he Tnrks may attempt to oooopy the Island of Faraon, which Engli-h cruisers will prevent lt is impossible to obtain a clear aooonnt of the matter, as the Porte pretends to know nothing, and the Palaoe claimi that the Egyptians bailt blookhoases on Tarkish territory; while the E^ypAans state that the Tnrks occupied Taba, where the Egyptians have been undisturbed sines 1892. Another version is that the Administration ot the Sinai Peninsala was given to the present Khedive personally by the Vieerial letter, as it was omitted from the original firman rf 1892, aud it is 'h before, not on the same footing as the rest of Egspt. This the English do not admit. It is generally supposed that the action was instigated by the Hedjsz o man sion in order to set back the frontier from Akaba, which will shortly bijoineiwith the Hedjaz railway, thus a quiring great strategio importance, being on the direot line of oom- munioations of Hedjaz and Syria."

"The Tribune,'' disonssing this qnestion in a leading artiole, predio's that the mistake is likely to be a foretaste of similar incidents in the fa tore. Turkey's object daring the last few years has been to confirm her grip upon Arabia, on which depends her religious asoen- danoy, and which the indomitable Arab tribes are oonBtantly shaking off. In proseontion of this idea she is pushing southward a railway yetem, designed by German engineers, of which the aims are more military than commercial. This, it has been suggested, will ultimately reach to the Yemen, the principal oentre of revolution where fighting on a considerable scale is, and for the last year has been, going on. What the result of the Turoo-®°,n5. . .... . ..ml the 12th inst., in the mighbourhood of Khatat- Thynne and her son, the Hon. Bvelyn Barirg.
A ablf) struggle Wll be, and W e he llirkey . uniW unnfidnntial inRtrnnt.innn whirh Lava , mk.- .awaarf Jnnm. Innnh W.I unitt mr.

wll be able to supply the neoeassry troops, a oouple of shiploads of whioh have just mutinied in the Red Sea for laok of pay, are open questions. What is oertain is that, if Turkey saooeeds in confirming her hold upon Arabia she will come into touch at various points with ns. "Questions" of the Sinaitio boundary, the Red Sea littoral, the Aden frontier, will bs rife, and are likely to be oomplioatsd by our semi allianoe with the insurgent tribes. 0 e suoh inoident we have had, and we shall have more anon.

div.head: THE SCHOOL STRIKE.
div.p: The technical students of the Boulac Scooll are now out on strike and in consequece run considerable risk of being expelled en bloc. According to the latest reports the pupils of the Agricultural School re alos on strike, though the interviews hled yesterdY MORNING BETWEEN THE DELEGATES OF THE AGGRIEVED law students and the authoritiws are said to giv ehope of a satisfactoy settlemtn. wE Are infromed that demands for no aftenoon schoola re absed on the fact that mnay of pupils who live at some distance form the lAW SCHOOL, ARE put to some expense by the necesioty of returning to the afternoon elcturea and that should the morning hours be prolonged to 12:30p.m. or to 1p.m. the whole day's course would be completed in the morning, and the sudents whose pare ts have already been put to greater expense by the raising of the fees-which rather unfairly in our opinion, is imposed retroactively-woul find it easier to make both ends meet. On the other hand, to allow students to go in and out of the school and presumbly the lecture rooms at all hours would be the nd of discipline and we consider tht while a pupil who fails in one examiniation should not b disqualified from re-entering, Unlimited facilities for re-entrance would roduce most unsatisfactory results.

to go in and out of the school and presumably the lecture rooms at all hour* would be the end of discipline and we oonsider that WuJc a pupil who fails in one examination should not be disqualified from re entering, Unlimited taodities for reentranos would prodnoe most unsatiaf-otory results.

We have no desire to be considered obscurantists in educational matters and acknowledge that in some respeots the educational machinery of the country works too rigidly. The raising of the fats from L.B. 15 to L.E 20 per annum seems to us to be jastified, but it hardly seems fair that the parents of pupils who entered the Law School bef re the Deome of Feb. 14 shoald be obliged to pay the extra amount. On the other hand we should like to remind the youthfal strikers that the violent and insalting language held at reoant public meetings, is hardly likely to bring the eduoational authorises to a conciliatory frame of mind. In any oase a strike will not benpfit the oaDse of ednoation (espeoiaily if aooompanied by windy harangaea), for a Government oan hard'y snbrait to dotation from Camaliels of from 18 11 20 years of age, least of all when external influence ot a subversive and reao ionary character is brought to bear ou the strikers.

We understand that it is not yet certain whether the Rtndents of the Law 8chool will return to work to-morrow or not. If they refuse we gather that they will be expelld. The government is ready to consider certain of the demands made by the strikers in a friendly spurit if they return to work tomorrow and if their conduct and industry prove satisfacory for a period of about two months.

the pupils of Ras-el-Tin School have telwgraphed to the Ministry of Public instruction to the thaat, if their fellow-students of the school of law do not have their wrongs redressed, they will als go on strike.

div.head: VICTORIA HOUSE. PROPOSED EXTENSION.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Dun Carlos,, the Duke of Madrid, and the Duoheu of Madrid gave a luncheon party at Shepheard's yesterday. The gnasts ware H. H. Prince Abbas Halim, Brig.-Geoerai, Mrs. and Miss Bullock, General and Mme de Medira, Baron and Baroness Biegeleben, Baron and Baroness Trantteoberg, .Count and Countess della Sala, Baron de Villebo'^ General Thurneyssen Paoha, Fakhry Paoha, M. and Mme Nubar, Mrs. Levedoff

Lord and Lady de Clifford have arrived in Cairo and are staying at the Savoy Hotel, where other arrivals inolude : Col. and Mr*. Fitzherbert, London; Mias Worthington, London; Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Wilkinson, London; Count Cesar Wartensleben, Wiesbaden; M. and Mme de Vilmorin, Paris; Count deDortan, Paris; Mr. and Mrs. Akton Adam», London; Mr. and Mrs. Heniy Staats, New York; eto.

Count John Bemstorff, who,as our telegrams to-day state, has been selected to sucoeed Baron Rucker-Jenisob as Diplomatio Agent and Consul-General at Cairo, has been Councillor and 1st Seoretary to the German Embassy in London sinoe 1902. He is himself a Londoner, baviDg been born there on November 14, 1862, the son of the late Count Allbreoht Bemstorff, himself Ambassador in London. He was educated at Dresden and in 1881 entered the German Army, joining the 1st Regiment of Artillery Guards. Ia 1889 he deoided to up the calling of his father and obtained a post as attache to the Embassy at Constantinople. Subsequently hearted as seoretary at Belgrade, Dresden, 8t Petersburg, and Munich. In 1887 he married Miss Jeanne Luokemeyer of New York. a M. Gennadis Hellenio Diplomatio Agent in Cairo, who was reoently summoned to Athens, is expected to return to Cairo on the 10th inat.
Sinoere sympathy will be felt with Sir Rennell and Lady Rodd, who were summoned home from Stockholm, immediately after their return there, by the illness of their little son.

Captain Gordon, R.A., and Mrs. Gordon left Alexandria yesterday afternoon by the Danera for Gibraltar. The Rev. Prebendary Carlile, head of the Church Army, has left London for the Riviera for the purpose of oolleoting funds to oarry on his emigration soheme. Later Mr. Carlile will visit Egypt, where he will make a short stay. Before leaving England Prebendary Carlile had an interview with King Edward, who made sympathetic enquiries with respeot to the social work of the Chnroh Army, and expressed his great interest in it

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY. . a » ■ FOOTBALL.
div.p: ST. ANDREW FTCT"«. E. T. 0. F. .0* The third meeting this season of the above olnbs took plaoe on Saturday last on the Sporting Club's ground at Ibrahimieh, kindly granted for the'match. The fixture ended in a goal lees draw. "Ths turf was somewhat greasy, and both teams had difficulty in keeping their feet, and in oonsequence the play was of A somewhat uninteresting nature. Combination was sadly laoking, and neitheir side oonld mnoh headway for a time. Both tims considerably under strength, however, and thie no donbt had something to do with the poor display of football. Ot the two teams, the Telegraph XI were slightly the better lot, but any ohanoea that they may have had of winning the game were thrown away by the desire on the part of some of the forwards to play to the gallery. Owing to the slippery oondition of the ground, good shooting was at a discount, and the custodians didn't have to maoh to do as might otherwise have been the oase. Curtis and Dowson performed with eqnal eredit for their reepeotive rides, between the upright*, everything that came to them being dealt with in masterly fashion. Curtis indeed in some of his saves was brilliant, particularly in stopping a rocket shot of Choeeman's in the first half and spooning one from the toe of Sheppard a few seconds later ; and again in the second half dealing smartly with a stiff •hot from Blythman. Dowson too had a lot to do to hold one of Constantinidis's efforts, and again looked in difficulties when I*rk tried him with a "daisy-cutter." Apart from these oooaaions neither gcal was much troubled. Thinks to the good work of the respective back-, piny was for the moot part confined to midfield, but was generally of a somewhat scrambling nature. Townsend was withoat doubt the best man on the field, bis taokling and passing being at all times well judged. The following were the team*:
St. Andrew F. C.:— Curtis, Keill, Cowie, Rofe, Shea, Ecclestone, Constantinidis, Jones, Lark, Tulloch, and Metzger.
Eastern Telegraph F. C.: —Dowson, Sedg- :ok, Soarth, Henley, Shepherd, Townsend, Blythman, 'ish, Lees, Cheesroan, Jacob. Referee. S, J. Dswsoo.
KHEDIVIEH t). TEWFIKIEH.

Alter a good matoh the Khedivieh Sohool XI. beat the Tewfikieh Sohool team by 2 goals to nil. The winners got the wit>d in the first half atd made good use of it, hiving the best of the game all through. In the seoond half the Tewfikieh XI. often pressed bat ooald not s-iOre, their shooting being rather high. The play .was deoidedly fast and on the whole good, though there was too mnoh arm work noticeable in the charges, one or two players literally handing off their opponents who tried to tMklf tbf».

div.head:
Algeciras
More Hopeful Feeling
STRONG INFLUENCES AT WORK.

div.p: Altogether a more hopeful feeling prevails here. Though the work of the Conference has made no progress, it is understood that various influences are working to draw Germany and France together, notably the Tsar, who is anxios for pacific setlement without which he cannot obtain the much-needed loan. (R.)
Official circles are optimistic. They believe that an agreement will be come to regarding the Morroco Bank.

House of Commons--Mr. Winston Churchill has accepted the motion urging that the Imperial Government should be responsible for the protection of natives in South Africa. he said that the Government was determined to insist in the proper treatment of natives by Colonial Governments: the veto would be applied to legislation infringing on the fundamental traditions of British liberty.
Referring to the events in Natal, Mr. Winston Churchill said that while there was no reason for immediate apprehension, the situation required careful and patient attention.
(Reuter)

div.head: The Natal Troubles. Chief Pays the Tax.

div.p: The chief of the disturbed district has submitted and paid the tax. The principal agitator, who is an educated native, has been arrested.
(Reuter)

div.head: Persian Gulf. No Anticipation of Trouble.

div.p: The "Tribune" learns from Colombo that H.M.S.Hogue has been ordered to the Persian Gulf, where trouble is expected.
Reuter's Agency is informed that H.M.S. Hogue's ordinary periodical visit to the Persian Gulf is in order to show her flag and is not connected with any expectation of trouble there.
An Englishman, Mr. Glanville, has been killed at Maaghil on the Shat-el Arab (Persian Gulf) while defending the Euphrates and Tigris Steamship Company's depot, by a band of Arabs, presumably robbers.
(REUTER)
An Anglo-French convention has been signed settling the differences with reference to the New Herbrides
The King will meet the Emperor William shortly, proably on board his ship.
Count. J Bernstorff, Secretary at the German Embassy in London, has een appointed Diplomatic Agent in Egypt. He will arrive in May.
The report of the New York Equitable states that the insurance scandal resulted in the company losing 22,000,000.

The Chamber have by 344 votes to 147, agreed to reduce the annual traingin of the reservists and territorial troops to 15 and 6 days respectively, despite the strenuous opposition of M. Rouvier, who declined to be a party to the weakening of the vital forces of the country.
Turbines engines willl be adopted on all vessels provided for in the present year.

div.head: PROSPECTUS
div.p: La Societe Anonyme The Egyptian Enterprise and Development Company a ete foundee le 26 Novembre 1904 au Capital de 160,000 divise eu 16,000 actions de L.E. 10 nominal entierement liberees.

Aux termes de ses status elle a pour objet l'etude, la preparation et l'execution pour son compte ou pour compte de tiers ou en participation de toutes operations en terrains et immeubles urbains ou ruraux, de construction de canux reservoirs, digues, drains,chemins de fer, tramways, d;enterprises d'irrigation et generalement de tous travanx d'amelioration ainsi que de toutes entreprises industrielles se rattachant a 'agriculture.

Depuis la fondation de la Societe, les affaires out immediatment pris un developpement tel que non seulement le capital original a ete juge insuffisant, mais que meme l'augmentation de capital de L.E. 40,000 prevue par les status n'aurait, mais que mem l'augmentation de capital de L.E. 40,000 prevue par les status n'aurait pas permis d'etendre suffisamment les affaires de la Societe.

Une assemblee generale extraordinaire des actionnaires tenue au Caire le 15 Decembre 1905 a approuve a l'unanimite la propistion du Conseil de proter le capital a 400,000 par l'emission de 24,000 Actions Nouvelles du meme type que les actions anciennes et participant aux benfices sociaux a partir du 1 Janvier 1906.

Cette augmentation de capital a ete ferme par un groupe de financiers belges dirige par la Banque de Reports de Fonds Publics et de Dpots a Anvers, et la Societe Generale Egyptienne pour l'Agriculture et le Commerce au Caire
Sur ces 24,000 actions nonvelles, il en a ete sourscrit 13,000 par les acciencs actionaires en vertu d'un droit de prefernce qui leur a ete reserve.
La solde soit 11,000 actions fait l'onjet de la presente emission et est offert au public au prix de L.E. 12 par action.

La Situation de la Societe telle qu'elle a ete exposee a l'Asemblee generale ordinaire tenue le 20 Janvier dernier est des plus satisfaissautes. Les beneficies realises dans le coutrant du premier excercise ont permis la distribution d'un dividende de 8 1/2% aux actions de capital et P.T. 35 aux parts de dividende.

L'excercice en cours represente des maintenant sous un aspect des plus favorables. un lot de terrain acquis l'au dermier vient d'etre realise avec un benfice d'environ L.e. 23,000 et des offres fermes ont ete faites a la Societe our diversautres terrains a des prix qui laisseraient un benefice immediat de plu de L.E. 40,000.
Certaines affaires en participation ont acquis une telle plus value que leur realisation immediate assurearait un benficee considerable.

Cea que'ques considerations suffront amplement pour demontar que des maintenatn la Societe a non seulement trouve un emploi remuneratwuer pour son nouveau capital, mais que l'on peut esperaer que les beneficies du present exercice suffrotn largement pour distribuer sur l'ensemble du capital de L.E. 400,000 des dividendes au moins quivalents a ceux de I'an dernier.

div.head: Egyptian Investment AND LEGACY
div.p: The second ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Investment and Agenoy, Ltd., wns held on the 2'2nd nit. at Winchester Honse, Old Broad street, London. E.C., Sir Frederio W. R. Fiyer, K.C.S.I , (Chairman oft he company), presiding.
The Secretary (Mr. H. 0. King) having read the notice convening the meeting and the report of the auditors.

The Chairman said : You will see that the resnlts of our first year's trading have been very satisfactory, particularly when you remember the short period of normal work (only eight months) that this first year has given ns, and the fact that there are, of course, oertain expenses incidental to the first year of the company's initiation which sre not likely to recnr. In the initial period i f a company like yonrs I need not remind you that some time and energy are necessarily expended in making trials to see what branches of business it is moat suitable to follow,and which are likely to prove the most lucrative. Yon will observe from the statement of accounts published with the report that we have made a net profit of £8 987 2s during the period under review.This is after deducting all working expenses in London and Egypt, and without taking any account of an appreciation in the value of our investments which, on the basis of a valuation made at practically the lowest point reaobed during the recent crisis on the Egypt:an Bourse, amounted to upwards of £10,00''. We have not thought it necessary to make a fresh valuation, though, in the meantime, prices have recovered considerably. At the present prices thU recovery j rough'y rep*e3ants an add tional £7.010, or a total appreciation of, say, £17,000,on the basis 1 of telegraphic advioes received yesterday from onr office in Alexandria. Ths expenses have ! baen kept down as f*r as possible ; we have limited ourselves to necessities,and we feel sure thatin the toture you can rely upon every effort being made to maintain snob economy as is consistent with cffhienoy Onr total preliminary expenses amonnt to £7 867 3s. 3d. Of these expenses we have written off one-third, or £2,622 78. 9d. This leaves a balance at credit of profit and lo°s account of £6 364 14s 3d. Oat of this the Boar.i propose to nay a dividend of 10 per cent, on the paid-up capital, free of inoome tax, which will absorb £5,0',0, leaving £1.364 14s. 3d. to be carried forward. Your direotors think that we may not unreasonably congratulate ourselves on this result.
Nmw Flotations
I

At onr statutory meeting, held on the 7th April last, I told yon that the fl itation in Egypt of one company by onr agency was prao- lically complete, and that the fi itation of another was very near completion. These two companies were the Building Lands of Egypt, Ltd., and the Associated Cotton Ginners of Egypt, Ltd. I am glad to sayUhat these two companies have justified our expectations and realised considerable profits. The Building Lands of Egypt, Ltd., has realised in the first few months of its existence a handsome return : on the small capital employed by it—namely, £75,000, out of a total capital of £150,000 — and by jadioions selection this company has avoided locking up its capital in land at high prices. It is true that the original issue of this company's shares was attended with unforeseen difficulties,as daring the long delay in obtaining the "Dsoree of Constitution" from the Egyptian Government a serious change bad come over the tone of the market there. People who had wished to p'artioipate in the formation of the company when the prospeotns wis first laid before them found that (quite apart from the intrinsic value of this undertaking) they, owing to the change in circnmqtat ces, were enable to embark in any new enterprises. In view, how- | ever, of onr knowledge of the valuable nature j of the project, we decided to proceed, and i BQOoessfully completed the issue. Our managing I direotor was able some time ago to report that this company would be able to place a consider able snm to resdrve, after paying the statutory dividend, as the result of the first six months' working. We are now in posse-s'on of the first report of this company, and from it we find that the amonnt avadabln for and being carried to reserve is £6,789, after providing a dividend of 5 per cent, on the paid-up capital, which, taking into account the amount already standing at credit of reserve, £2,682 (set aside from the preminm on the iBsae after dedooting all preliminary expenses), will bring the reserve up to £9,471. The lands it holds have been taken at co-t price, and represent at the valuation of to-day further material profit. We hold 6,505 ordinary shares (£4, with £2 paid), together with 550 founders shares, which latter have been dealt in at £8 and we think very well of the proppects of the Company. We have no other interest in land.
Ammoolatmd Cotton Olnnerm' Company.

The A sociated Cot»on Gmuers of Egypt, Ltd., wbiob is the second company I alluded to at our statutory meeting, and which oocu pied onr attention in the spring, has had a baocessfal industrial start. Unfortunately, as in the case of the Bnilding Lmds Company, the i.*sne of the company's shares cauie at an unpopular moment on the Egyptian Burse, and the assess and advantages of the undertaking were overlooked. The undoubted value of the properties taken over, and of the goodwill of the business, which was not included in the valnation, will, yonr directors feel confident, be folly appreciated when the first balance-sheet, is issued in the spring. Yonr directors consider that this is a commercial undertaking of the first importance, with every prospect of earning handsome 'dividends in the fotnre. Th*y have, in addition to the original hqlding, bought shares from time to time, and in all we now hold 29,750 £1 shares, which yonr directors consider a first-olass investment. We hold 2,900 shares of 10s each in the Port Sa,id Salt Company. This company will, yonr Board are ir formed, unite w:th the Egyp'io^lalt apd Soda Company, and has, they believe,"S-gOod future before it. The only other shares we h >ld are 400 of the.DairaSanieh Company. We have discounted selected looal paper to advantage, obtaii ing a gor d retorn on money invested, and there is in contemplation a considerable extension of this branc h of onr business. The Board have also under their consideration some attrao tive projects and plans, and hope to succeed in making some of them sound money earners. The Board contemplate that, in the future, it willle expedient to give the London market filler opportunities of participating in any new operations that the company may andertake than has been possible in the past. Daring 19^4 the supply of local shares in Egypt was insufficient for the demand, cansing inflation of prices, while new creeli >ns in 1905 have in Egypt, in the meantime, overstocked the market. However, mo*t of the schemes are well based and proqjae a good return, and Egypf is still increasing its wealth.
Thm Prosperity of Egypt.

Our managing director in Egypt confirms th« opinion of the Board that the prosperity of Egypt has not yet reached its zeni'h and that its commercial prospects are excellent. It is not solely due to a speculative instinct that investors have seemed to exaggerate the value of the retnrn due to oapital, as is, in some quarters, suggested. Looal Egyptian investor# have made large realisations recently in profits on cotton, lands, and etc. They prefer to place these profits in ooncerns personally known to them, which they can in most oases follow, and conseqnently consider as safer investments. Owing to a favourable arrangement made with onr bat kera in Egypf, wo have been able to use considerable sums at moderate rates to mne-h advantage to onrselvep, and have thus avoided the necessity of calling up any 'additional oapital. In this connection v may be nofed that it is far more economical for ns to have called up only 25 per cent, of our capital, as, when we have only a fourth of onr capital called np, we retain a great reserve of credit, wbith is Irghly beneficial in negotiating Vg issues, whereas, if all our oapital were oa'led up and placed at a high rate, it would be apt to become immobilised for the purpose of such negotiations.
Thm Company's Polloy.

Our oo npmy's policy has been, and is, to be ready to undertake financial and commercial work, or aot as brokers, and generally to undertake any business that snits ns. For this reuon we have inaugurated a commercial branch at A1 ex anIria from which all speculation is rigorously excluded, which will work with clients known to ns, and aot as agents for British and other firms who desire a responsible andaotive agent in Egypt. With a small oapital, jndicionsly nsed, solid pn fit will, yonr direotors hope, be realised by this branch, having regard to the home and local connections which we possess. Yonr direotors are particularly glad to be able to tell yon that they have been able to maintain yonr position liquid, and it is a satisfaction to feel that we baYe no large blocks of land, or, in faot, any land, which, while showing handsome profits on paper, may take a long time to realise. We hive written ofi one-third of our preliminary expenses, and have decided to recommend yon to di-t'ibote £5,000 of the net pr^fi's remaining, constituting a dividend of 10 per cent., free of income-tax, on the paid-up oapital. We have not deemed it recessary to make any special payment to reserve, as onr investments themselves, though this is not shown in the accounts, do what is necessary, i.e., hold a good and increasing snm to reserve.
Future Prospoots.

We may, we think, look forward to a steady and incre-sing income from onr general bnsiuess, a good interest from onr in- ve-tments, and we hup* considerable profits from fime to time from fresh financial operations as they may present themselves. Before conoluditg what I have to say of onr first year's operations, I mnst call yonr attention to the great ability and energy which onr managing director in Egypt (Mr. Abdy) has displayed in the condnot of onr business. He has thoroughly justified onr confidence in him, Mr H. 0. King, onr secretary here, Mr. Mieli, onr manager in E.'^pt, and our staff in Egypt and in London, deserve onr cordial thanks for the teal ard devot on they have shown to onr interests. We have, I think, been very fortunate in the selection of onr personnel, who have worked most loyally. Major Villiers and Mr. Owen have retired from onr Board since the statutory meeting, and the Board . in January appointed Mr. C. Stewart Cox a director. Mr. Stewart Cox has been associated with the comjauy from the begin1 inor, and has been a mo3t valuable and efficient ooadjntor in all masters that have o >me t-efore the Board. We bone that tb>s meeting will confirm the seleo'ion of Mr C Stewart Cox as » d rector. I now propo-e : ' That the directors' nport and statement of accounts for the period ending 31st, December, 1905. be adopted.''
Mr. R. P. Sellon seconded the motion, which was carried unanimnmly without di- cjssion.

The Chairman next proposed : "That a dividend of 10 per cent., free of income-tax, on the paid up capita! of*the company—£50 000 —be declarer?, payable on the 1st March, 1906, absorbing £5,000 of the balance at the credit of pn fit and loss account, and that £1,364 14s 3d be carried forward."
Captain Holland seconded the resolution, which was agreed to.
The Chairman then mnvad that Mr. C. Stewart Cox be re-eleoted to a seat on the Board.
Captain Holland said that he had mnch pleasure in seconding the resolution, tor he well knew that Mr. Cox had been of the greatest possible assistance to the company during the past year.
The resolution was unanimously carried.
On the motion of Mr. Baty, seconded by Captain Holland, the auditors.Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, were reappointed at a fee of £100.

Captain Holland remarked that be oonld not allow the proceedings to terminate without proposing a hearty vote of thanks to the Chairman and direotors for their services during the past year. He considered that the shareholders had every reason to oongratnlate themselves upon the snocess which had attended the operations of the oompany during the firet year of its existence.
Mr. Baty seconded the resolution, and in doing so said that the shareholders were greatly indebted to the direotors for snoh a favourable result of the year's working.
The resolution was oarried by acclamation.

The Chairman : I am very mnoh obliged to the shareholders for their vote of thanks, and I may say that my colleagues and myself have given onr must careful attention to yonr business. As Captain Holland has said, we have every reason to congratulate ourselves on a successful year's business, and I trust that the fntnre of the oompany may be as bright as the beginning has been. (Applause.)
The proceedings theu terminated.

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: KEARSLKY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT.
Liverpool, February 22.
A fair business has been done in Egyptian this week ; the quotations of Fair, Fully Good Fair, and Good Brown, are unchanged, Good Fair and Fine being ^d.per lb higher.
In Fatnres a good business has been done, and the following are the latest values :
Feby. n.43d May 8.40 Ang. 8.36
Mch. 8.42 June 8.38 Sept. 8.28
Apl. 8.41 July 8.36 Oct. 8 20

American Futures. The Market this week opened steadier, and prices advanced 4 points; later, under renewed pressure to sell and an absence of speculative demand, prices fell away day by day, to-day's closing values being 12 @ 14 points below those of last Thursday. There is no special feature ; orop movements oontinne on a free scale, Now York and New Orleans have been sellers, and there is no fresh speculative disposition. At the same time markets mast be well sold oat now, and we aro disposed to think that any favourable change in the sitnati-m would be quickly seized upon, and a more or less sharp rally would ensno. Trade oontiunes highly satisfactory : and at the same time we do not believe in any fresh Ball" campaign, except upon unfavourable planting and weather conditions. div.head: Chronique Judiciaire. Tribunal mIXTE DU cAIRE. Accident au Canal de Suez
div.p: La 2me Chambre civile da Tribanal mixte pr^sid^e par M. Herzbruch a reodn aonjnge ment dans le proems intent^ par le Dr Velten, medeoin masseur, poor une ebate qa'il fit le 13 dijembre 1904 en debarquant da qaai de Port-Tewfik (Suez), faote de l'dclairage de ce qaai. Le mldecin eat ane luxation du bras et de l'^paule ganche et rdolamait 4000 LE.

Par une qoinzaine d'atteudas, le Tribunal constate que le goavernement est responsable de Tijlairage et de l'entretien da qnai et (fWen vain il al'kgne qa'il n'y a auonne loi qui Ini impose d'kclairer les qnais d'un port on d'on autre lieu public. La Compagnie da Canal est mise hors de oaase et le goavernement est oon- damnd k payer 800 LE. et les intdrfits k 5/a an Dr. Velten, somme reconnue sulfisante, oonnne indemnity.
Nouveau Conseiller Hellenique'
M. Stoupis, conseiller and la Cour de cassation hell Unique, nomm4 j age an tribunal mixte de Mansoarah en remplaoement de fea M. Boopbi dis, est attendu au Caire, la semaine proohaine.

div.head: Circulaipe H. de Vpies et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Cairo, ler mars.

A Londres, le Conaolidl anglais a encore hansel de 1/4 de livre k 91. L'Unifide a ^gale- ment gagnd 3/8 k 105 3/8. Par contre, la National Bank et ia Daira Banieh sont reopeignis en reaction de 1/8 k 27 3/8 et 17 3/4. L'Agri- cole est rest^e inchang^e k 10.
A Paris, Taction Crkdit Foncier Egyptien a progress^ de 1 franc k 793 et la Banqae d'A thknes de 3 traces k 145.
/A
Notre marohri des valenrs n'a pas montrd, co matin, beanconp d'animation ; La skanoe a 6t6 calme dans preeqne tons les compartiments.

Pea d'afiaires en National Bank et en Agri- cole, qui ont pins on moms olOtarl k lears prix d'hier. La Banqae d'Atbknes a avanc^ k 144— 145. Le Comptoir Financier est revena k 5 11/16 et la Banqne d'Abyssinia k 6 13/16.

L'aotion Credit Foncier est res toe k 794. La Daira Sanieh se maintient k 18 aohetenrs ; on parle toojours d'une prochaine repartition de £ 10 par action k laquelle nous avions fail allnsion U y a quelques jours.
En bonne tendance, la Bebdra a avance k 38- L'Agtioule du Nil a remouto k 271 ; la part de fondatenr fait 6 13/ 6.
La part de foud-tteur Eutreprise and Development a encore gagito une livre k 14 aobeteurs.
L'action capital Eanx da Cairo est k 124— 125; la part de jonissauoe k 277.
L'action Soctoto fTEutrepriaea et dedPravaox se traite eDtre 3 15/iG et 4; la part de fonda- teur est toojoors demandde k L.E. 7 3/4. j
Lea dividendes Tramways d'Alexandtie re- prennent k 315.
Dans le gronpe des Hdtels, les Baehler re-, montent k 5 et les Upper Egypt k 5 5/8 ache* j tears.
Parmi les petites valenrs, les Delta restent k £ 1/4, les Hooker de 11/10 k 11/8, les Estates a 1 7/8 et les Abdy k 3/8 vendaars. m
Les actions ordinaires Khedivial Mail avan- oent k 87, les New Egyptian k 30, les Oads de 11/8 k 3/16, les Qlymenopoulo de 1 8/8 k 7/16, lea Salt and Soda k 26sh. 6 et les Cotton Mills k 7 sb. 3.
L'imission des 68,000 aotions k £ 1, otTertes k la so ascription pnblique par l'Egyptian Cons truotions Ltd., a iti oouverte 9 foia k Alexandria et 6 foia au Cairo, soit quinze foia en tout.
Les risultats ont iti trails k 1/8 et le ferme k 1/4 de prime, acheteurs.

La Compagnie lmmobilikre d'Egypte, continuant la skrie de ses brillantes operations, vient encore de realiser un benefice important par la vente de 1'ex-propriete Burelli, qu'elle avait .icqui-e anx environs de 10 livres le mktre. La cession s'est efifectoee au prix de £ 16, soit une bonification de £ t> par mktre, plus an droit de participation k la moitie des benehoea youvant fitre realises par i'acqndreur.
La propriete ayant une Buperfioie de 2,800 mktres environ,oela represente dqno un benefice immediat de 14,000 livres sans oompter les eapd ranees.

On rapports qae l'Egyptian Estates Co. vient d'aoheter l'Hdtel du Nil an Mousky. La propriete a une superfioie d'environ 7,300 pics. L'acquisition aurait 6c6 faite k des oonditionB qui promettraient an benefice considerable.

Ou r*pporte, d'autre part, que 1'Egyptian Land Investment Co. a vendu poor LE. 30,900 environ le terrain ooonpe autrefois par les ateliers Antofage k Alexandria. Le benefioa total realite par la Societe sur cette affaire serait de prks de 11,000 livres.
Les travaox d'agrandissement da National Hotel avanoent rapidement. Les entrepreneurs se sont engages k'livrer cette annexe k l'ex- ploitation dks le 30 novembre proobain.

div.head: Vade Mecum for the Homeward Bound
Picture Post Cards
div.p: "The Egyptian Gazette" Series is the most artistic collection to be found in Egypt.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera, and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe. Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list showing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 4 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers, of the P.andamp;O. North German Lloyd, Orient and Messageriea Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, and Bibby Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said, can now be made without change in 4 1/2 hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.
The most expensive but quickest through Continental routes are by P.andamp;O. Brindisi express from Port Said, and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; hero there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Donino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.

On every floor there are special baths of Muriated lodo Fromine waters. Moderate charges. For prolonged stay, pension rates.

The various medical appliances fulfill the utmost demands of modern science, and furnish every thing necessary for Hydropathic, mechanical, and electric treatment.
For propectus and Tariff, please apply to the Proprietor of Hotel Titlis and the Kuranstalt.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY (Continued) and The ITALIAN LAKES.
div.p: VENICE is a 5 hours journey by rail from Milan, and one of the most delightful places imaginable to pass a quiet stay. The total absence of vehicular traffic strikes one as very strange ; no horse, cart, carriage or bicycle is to be seen, and yet there is the sound of life at every turn. The approach to Venice from the Adriatic is unlike that of any other sea port. The town seems to be gradually, like Aphrodite, born of the sea, no hills behind, no stretches of rock, but first the tops of Campaniles appear above the horizon, then slowly the whole glittering town rises like a fairy mirage out of the calm lagoon.
Going northwards from Milan you make the tour of the beautiful Italian lakes.
COMO, the birthplace of the younger Pliny, is reached in one-and-a-quarter hours by train by way of Monza :

Boats leave Como frequently for the other towns on the lake, which is very beautiful, and the scenery on either side going up the lake is most enchanting. CERNOBBIO is a charming spot; then come Tremezzo, Cadenabbia, and Menaggio with the prettily-situated town of Bellaggio opposite. The walk from Tremezzo along the shore of the lake to Menaggio is most enjoyable. A steam tram runs from Menaggio to Porlezza on Lake Lugano in three-quarters of an hour, then steamer to Lugano in two-and-three-quarter hours.

div.head: SWITZERLAND.
div.p: Switzerland, the heart of Europe, has been described as "A cluster of delights and grandeurs."

LUGANO is some 20 miles from Como and reached by train in one-and-a-half hours. It has a population of 10,000 people and is charmingly situated on the Lake of Lugano, amidst lovely Italian scenery. Around it rise M. San Salvatore, M. de Caprino.and M. Generoso.

LOCARNO, may be reached by rail from Bellinzona in forty minutes. This pretty town, situated at the top of lake Maggiore has a mild climate and is an excellent winter resort. The church Madonna del Sasso, situated above the town, is worth a visit, as it contains interesting paintings, "Entombment," by Ciseri, and 'Tho Flight into Egypt," by Bramantion.
LUCERNE—A striking picture on the Lake of Lucerne facing the Rigi and Pilatus and the snow-clad Alps.
In and around the town the walks are charming, and the excursions to be made from Lucerne by boat, rail, etc., are very numerous.

The Lake of Lucerne abounds in delightful excursions, those to the Rigi, Pilatus, Burgenstock and Sonnenberg needing a special visit each. Other excursions on the lake can be made by steamer, and the ever-changing scenery on the trip from Lucerne, to Fluelen is a source of delight to the lover of nature.

BRUNNEN, charmingly situated on the most beautiful part of the Lake of Lucerne, commands magnificent views of lake and mountain scenery. Along the Lake of Uri from Brunnen to Fluelen runs the famous Axentrasse

A delightful exeption from Lucerne is that to ENGELBERG. Take boat to Stansstad and from Stansstad it is about 1 hour and 40 min. by Electric Railway, with delightful scenery en route. The ascent of Titlis, is made from here, and the panoramic view of the Alps is grand; extending from Monte Rosa to the Black Forest, and from the Santis to the Matterhorn.

THE BERNESE OBERHAND.-INTERLAKEN a favourite summer resort and the best centre for making excursions in the Oberland, abounding in fine walks and views. There is a magnificent view of the Jungfrau from the Hoheweg, a fine avenue of walnut trees the chief resort of visitors. Interlaken is also not far from the famous waterfalls, Giessbach, Trummelbath and Staubbach. Then also the glaciers of Grindelwald and view from Murren and the Schynige Platte are sights not to be missed.

CHATEAU D'OEX. 3,500 ft above the sea on the new Electric Railway between Montreux and Interlaken, surrounded by magnificent scenery, with pure dry air. Much frequented by English people in Summer and Winter.

div.head: GREECE and IONIAN ISLES.
div.p: Many people visit Greece after wintering in Egypt, as it is so easily reached from Alexandria ; the climate in April is charming. The best steamers are those of the Khedivial Mail Co. and the Russian Steam Navigation Co.

If possible tourists should arrange to be in Athens for the Orthodox Easter in order to witness the Good Friday and Easter Eve ceremonies, and to be present at the dancing on the Easter Tuesday festival held at Megara for which a special train is run from Athens.
It is worth while to spend a few days in CORFU on account of the beauty of the scenery. There is also good snipe and quail shooting to be had.

div.head: LAKE OF LUCERNE. Grand Hotel, Axen-Fels.
div.p: Best Spring resort. 2,200 ft. above the sea. Every comfort.

The leading Hotel for English and American families. Trains every fifteen minutes by Electric Railway from Brunnen to Axen-Fels. The Park having a frontage of nearly a mile on the lake, is one of the prettiest in Switzerland.
World-wide reputation.
P: Sohnack, Proprietor
Level Wooded Walks.

div.head: LIDO (VENICE) LIDO
div.p: From Vernon or Lido, 12 min by steamboat. Climatic Station and Sea Baths, with Chinesitherapic Institute. Express between the station and Lido for the hotels.

div.p: The most important bathing station in Italy. ____ Restaurant and Terrace on the sea. Hydrotherapic institute. Concerts daily, frequented by the highest classes of society.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL DES BAINS.
div.p: Adjoining the sea. First-class hotel with dependencies andamp; chalets. 200 rooms andamp; saloons. Electric light. Aqueduct. Every modern comfort. Delightful residence, without any mosquitos.

div.head: THE GRAND HOTEL LIDO.
div.p: Hotel with its dependencies (Swiss Hotel), in the most delightful situation of the Lido at the landing place, five minutes walk from the bathing place. Wonderful view of the Legune of Venice. Room from 3 lire, with board from 8.50 per day. No mosquitos. Very dry and safe air.
Address- SOCIETE BACHI, LIDO, VENICE, ITALY.
